Yamtl Augmenting Java

15 Jan 2020 - -

YAMTL: Augmenting Java Programs with Model Transformation

YAMTL is a model transformation language that provides a fresh approach to model transformation by favouring interoperability, reuse, expressivity and efficiency.

Model transformation is traditionally used to translate models between different modeling languages and it can also be used to manipulate data that is modeled using an object-oriented notation, such as UML. This defining characteristic makes it an ideal candidate for developing low-code application platforms by, for example, automating both translation tasks and reverse engineering tasks.

YAMTL approaches model transformation (MT) language by means of an internal domain-specific language of Xtend and, thereby, reuses advanced IDE support and out-of-the-box interoperability with Java, including Android. Its transformation engine is one of the fastest thanks to working with compiled transformations.

YAMTL is a model transformation language fully interoperable with Java, expressive and very fast - arturboronat.info/yamtl

YAMTL comes equipped with advanced model transformation features that can help in implementing any kind of model transformation: as expressive as state-of-the-art model transformation languages, such as ATL; powerful model pattern matching with local-search programmable plans; reuse via multiple rule inheritance and module composition; compiled to Java; full interoperability from/to Java; additional facilities inherited from Xtend (templates for code generation, IDE, debugger, and Java extensions).

The following slides (used at MODELS’18) contain an example that shows some similarities between YAMTL and ATL:

In a recent survey on the future of MT languages, respondents enumerated a number of reasons for not using MT languages. In the table below, we indicate how YAMTL tackles some of those challenges:

Reason for not using MT YAMTL solution
Complex setup and IDE-specific dependencies Use mature Xtend IDE/Java ecosystem
No real debugging Use mature Xtend/Java debugging techniques
Not adapted to the web As a Maven dependency, YAMTL can be used in Java web projects (server-side)
Performance Our experiments [MODELS18, TTC18, FASE19, TTC19] show that performance is a strong point of YAMTL
ATL when simple transformations, Java when complex transformations YAMTL raises the level of abstraction for complex transformations
Cost in training staff Use plain Java with the YAMTL dependency

Trying YAMTL…

Using a YAMTL transformation is as easy as…

  1. Importing the YAMTL dependency in your Java project.
  2. Declaring a model transformation. See any of the following examples:
    • Instantiating behavioural models into deployment models from the VIATRA CPS Benchmark used in the MODELS’18 paper and in the FASE’19 paper
    • Transforming class diagrams to relational schemas from the FASE’19 paper
    • Querying social networks (Query 1 and Query 2) from the TTC’18 paper
    • Transforming truth tables to BDDs from the TTC’19 (tt2bdd) paper
    • Verifying consistency relations from the TTC’19 (bib2doc) paper
  3. Executing the model transformation:
// INSTANTIATE THE TRANSFORMATION DECLARATION
val xform = new cd2db

// PREPARE MODELS
xform.loadInputModels(#{'cd' -> inputModelPath})

// EXECUTE TRAFO 
xform.execute()

// STORE MODELS
var String outputModelPath = '''src/main/java/cd2db/targetInitial.xmi'''
xform.saveOutputModels(#{'db' -> outputModelPath})

Want to know more?

If you want to know more about YAMTL, check the following resources:

  • Information about YAMTL
  • YAMTL tool web page
  • Feel free to contact me if you need help in applying the tool.
  • Papers analysing the performance of YAMTL:
    • Artur Boronat. Expressive and Efficient Model Transformation with an Internal DSL of Xtend. MODELS’18.
    • Artur Boronat. Offline Delta-driven Model Transformation with Dependency Injection. FASE’19.
    • Solutions to cases of the tool transformation contest: TTC’18 paper, TTC’19 (tt2bdd) paper, TTC’19 (bib2doc) paper

Hola Jordi,

Bon any nou (i dècada)!

Abans de que es complís un any de la invitació inicial, he escrit una breu introducció a YAMTL: https://modeling-languages.com/?p=7339&preview=true

Disculpa el retràs.

He escrit un draft però m’agradaria retocar la imatge. He emprat el tamany recomanat 850x500 (https://modeling-languages.com/write-for-us-netiquette-rules/) però no apareix bé.

També m’agradaria embeure la presentació de MODELS18 però no ho he aconseguit, el WordPress Shortcode no funciona i per alguna raó el iframe és borrat per l’editor. Saps com incloure-la?

D’altra banda, estem organitzant el tool transformation contest per a enguany i ens agradaria oferir-te l’oportunitat de continuar el debat que obrires l’any passat sobre el futur transformacions de models a STAF. La idea seria explorar amb més detall com de llunyà queda que IA automatitze la definició de transformacions de models emprant eines concretes. Una manera de fer-ho seria proposant un cas d’estudi basat en exemples de transformacions en un domini d’aplicació concret de manera que gent treballant en llenguatges de transformació puguen definir-les. La idea seria discutir la tensió entre expressivitat i automatització, incloguent productivitat per a l’usuari de les eines. Trobes aquesta idea interessant? Saps algún domini d’aplicació concret on IA puga tindre un avantatge? Nosaltres podem donar una maneta en preparar el cas d’estudi. Si estàs interessat, podràs trobar més informació sobre el que es demana normalment en https://www.transformation-tool-contest.eu/cfc.html

Si et sembla bé t’enviaré una altre correu en anglés i copiaré als altres organitzadors de TTC.

Salutacions,
Artur
